Too many African politicians and sometimes local businesses, lawyers and civil society groups are quick to say, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our oil. It‚Äôs our country.‚Äù They take an ‚Äúus versus them‚Äù attitude, as if ‚Äúthey‚Äù are coming in to steal our resources. We need to move away from the ‚Äúmy country, my oil‚Äù mindset. It‚Äôs wrong, and it‚Äôs hurting our industry and average people. We must be honest with ourselves and recognize that resource nationalism‚Äîa country‚Äôs efforts to maintain tight-¬≠fisted control of its resources‚Äîis just as bad as racism or sexism. 
I know they argue that it is OUR oil. It is true. But until we have the ability (technical and financial wherewithal) to extract our oil and gas like bp , Kosmos Energy , Woodside Energy Chevron ExxonMobil TotalEnergies , and others do, why are we adding roadblocks instead of incentivizing production? Sometimes, I think our governments simply ignore the fact that investors are spending a lot of money to make these projects work and that their successes will be, eventually, our own.
Xenophobic feelings about expatriates or foreigners coming into our countries to work infect the entire system. And that, in turn, affects the African people we want to protect and empower. Africans have been around the world, and we have marched and protested to be treated with decency and respect as human beings. 
When we operate from a mindset of resource nationalism, we bring the very attitude we have fought against to our own business dealings. We are less likely to create an enabling environment for investment, less likely to be transparent, less likely to develop effective local content policies, and less likely to benefit from knowledge-¬≠sharing, capacity building, and valuable public-¬≠private partnerships. We have never seen a country grow stronger and more prosperous as a result of resource nationalism‚Äîand if we wade into that territory, we stand to lose.
#communitygrowth #africanenergy #sharingresources

$XOM $CVX $SHEL $GALP.PL $TTE $BP $SEI.V World's Largest Oil Discovery in >10 Years is Up for Sale
(1) As XOM and CVX battle in international courts over the right to buy $HES 30% interest in Stabroek Block (Guyana), a ~40% interest in 9,890 sq km offshore block in Namibia (PEL 83) that produced the world‚Äôs largest oil discovery in >10 years is up for sale. Galp Energia‚Äôs first two exploration wells in PEL 83 produced a >10B boe discovery, Mopane. Galp is only a >$3B EBITDA company. It is too small to fund development of its 80% interest in PEL 83 and is looking for a larger partner to fund its development.
While future PEL 83 development costs will require tens of billions of USD, these are >20% IRR investments at Brent $70/bbl. PEL 83 is one of the few scalable oil projects in the world, and unlike Stabroek Block, it does not have an angry neighbor (Venezuela) claiming it. There should be numerous bidders on PEL 83 and the following is only SPECULATION of whom they will be.
(2) Before any additional discoveries, the Mopane discovery likely translates to 350k-400k bpd by the early 2030's, comparable to Diamondback Energy‚Äôs $FANG 357k liquids production in 2023 (current $40.7B Ent Value). Galp has confirmed plans to drill 4 new exploration and appraisal wells around its world-class Mopane discovery. Considering the additional 6 identified prospects north of Mopane, future production of 600k-800k bpd is within reason.
(3) As Exxon and Chevron battle over rights to Stabroek Block in Guyana, the two are also likely bidders for PEL 83 given their excellent financial resources, deepwater experience and strong balance sheets. Chevron will begin drilling exploration wells in PEL 90 (adjacent to PEL 83) in 4Q24/1Q25. Exxon‚Äôs balance sheet is underleveraged and could easily be used to fund both Guyana and Namibia oil projects.
Shell‚Äôs block in Namibia is also adjacent to PEL 83 and is likely headed toward development after its discoveries. Shell is experienced in deepwater, has financial resources and also curiously drilled the Cullinan-1 well in 2023, within very close proximity of Galp‚Äôs 80% of PEL 83.
TotalEnergies has a large development ahead of it in Namibia following its Venus and Mangetti discoveries, in addition to prospects in South Africa it will begin exploring in 2025. Also considering Total‚Äôs Suriname, Nigeria, Angola and LNG project pipeline, the French IOC likely already has a full menu of capital projects.
Angola-based Azule Energy (BP and Eni JV) could be an interested party after announcing a farm-out with Rhino Resources in Namibia shortly after the Mopane discovery. BP is potentially looking to replace reserves it lost via its Rosneft write-down in 2022. Other potential bidders include Equinor, Petrobras and CNOOC.
(4) A potential PEL 83 sale would likely be a 2025 event, as Galp and Chevron drill more exploration wells in late 2024 and Namibia‚Äôs general election is in November. Namibia‚Äôs state-oil company, NAMCOR, will likely retain its 10% interest. Custos Energy also owns 10% (Sintana owns 49% of Custos). H/T to Sintana for their investor presentations.

NAMIBIA IS AFRICA'S NEXT MAJOR ENERGY HUB
----------------------------------------------
I discussed the prospects of Namibia's new oil and gas boom on @trtworld the other day. I am very optimistic about the country's socio-economic prospects.
1. Namibia is the "new Guyana" following a trio of significant play-opening oil discoveries in the Orange basin with the potential for up to 11 billion barrels of crude oil.
2. Buoyed by the country's political stability, high-impact drilling is expected to continue in Namibia.
3. Several majors such as Shell, TotalEnergies, Galp, Chevron, Azule Energy and ExxonMobil have acquired or are in the process of acquiring acreage.
4. Subject to FIDs, Namibia could produce between 500,000 to 1 million barrels a day by the mid-2030s. This would make it among the top five oil producers on the continent
5. Namibia is also looking to become a green industrial hub by producing green hydrogen for local, regional, and external markets in Europe. According to expert analysis,¬†Namibia¬†can theoretically produce some of the most cost-competitive¬†green hydrogen and green ammonia¬†globally using its vast solar and wind resources. In May 2023, Hyphen Hydrogen Energy agreed a deal with the Government of Namibia for a $10 billion green hydrogen project.
5. Namibia's US$13 billion GDP could double or even triple by 2040,¬†but the country would have to do more to translate this newfound resource wealth into equitable development and structural transformation--- governance/institutional reforms to address the large unemployment and inequality (NB: there are lots of good and bad lessons abound on the continent from Ghana to Nigeria).

Dan Pickering of Pickering Energy Partners, a consulting group, said:

Chevron and Hess; Diamond Back Energy and Endev Energy; Western Oil Company and Kronlock; Chesapeak Energy Company and Southwest Energy.

Since the Mopane discovery in late April, Chevron acquired an 80% stake in PEL 82 and Azule (BP and Eni) acquired 42.5% of PEL 85 in Namibia.
Exxon‚Äôs Liza Phases 1 and 2 are two FPSO‚Äôs producing ~400k bpd. While very early, Mopane‚Äôs well results indicate a similar potential. Galp announced it will drill an additional 4 exploration and appraisal wells for Mopane and has more prospects to the north in PEL 83.
(2) While long-cycle tailwinds appear supportive of offshore capex, Transocean‚Äôs 1Q24 earnings reminded investors the oilfield services business can have its bumps. RIG‚Äôs Revenue Efficiency (converting backlog into revenues) was 92.9% in ~1Q, a disappointing print considering their 96.9% average in the prior 4 quarters (VAL deepwater averaging 93.8% since began reporting in ‚Äò23). This was likely an aberration for RIG.
(3) Steady Climb Higher: In a sign of underlying demand growth and discipline, 7G drillship dayrates are performing better than feared a few months ago. After Noble Viking at $499k, Deepwater Asgard at $505k and Deepwater Atlas (15k work) at $505k, the 7G drillship market has officially pierced the $500k/day threshold. Further, RIG stated on 1Q24 call it expects a few additional market wide awards in the Gulf of Mexico above $500k/day in the next few months. VAL also indicated mid-to-high $400k‚Äôs for term contracts globally, an indication of good underlying demand for current sidelined 7G drillship capacity (~10 floaters).
(4) Tidewater reported excellent results this week, benefiting from a strong Offshore Supply Vessel (OSV) market. Leading edge dayrates in Platform Supply Vessels (PSV) are now $30k after bottoming in low $10k‚Äôs in 2016-2021. PSV‚Äôs carry cargo to offshore drilling rigs, amongst other services. When compared to deepwater drillships and semisubmersible rigs, OSV‚Äôs generally work on shorter term contracts allowing them to capture dayrate appreciation faster. While drillships are much more expensive to build new (very unlikely this decade), OSV demand is expected to grow when the ~10 sidelined 7G drillships gradually return to work.

First, a rhetorical question. Why is Israel's oil trade such a big, genocidal, deal? Because local supplies of crude oil are almost non-existent and because Israel's war effort would grind to an immediate halt without an assured supply of crude oil for its refineries and petroleum products such as military jet fuel that its refineries do not produce. The only reason Israel's blood-stained jets continue to operate is because the United States sent the necessary fuel tankers to Israel in the form of military aid. It is said that, except for what comes from America, all other supplies have disappeared.
But, Israel‚Äôs armed forces also uses large amounts of diesel fuel and gasoline for its tanks, bulldozers, and personnel carriers, which can be supplied by Israel‚Äôs own oil refineries, providing they receive uninterrupted supplies of crude oil from abroad. Fortunately for Israel, crude oil has been easy to obtain.
Since October 2023, Israel imported its crude oil from Azerbaijan through Georgia and Turkey, from Kazakhstan through Russia, and from Gabon and Brazil, with small amounts from the UAE, Iraq, and Saudi Arabia being routed through Egypt. Of these, Kazakhstan was the largest supplier and Azerbaijan the second largest. If either of these two countries would cease to export crude oil to Israel and if no other country took up the slack, then Israel's ability to wage a genocidal war of offense would come to a complete halt. If other countries joined in a boycott, Israel would be forced to negotiate an immediate, permanent, two-state, peace agreement with the Palestinians.
Companies supplying Israel with most of its crude oil and other petroleum imports are BP, Chevron, Exxon Mobil, Shell, Eni, and TotalEnergies. In the case of Azerbaijan, its pipeline through Georgia and Turkey is owned by BP, Equinor, Eni, TotalEnergies and Exxon. BP also produces some of the oil in cooperation with SOCAR, an Azeri company.
Oil from Kazakhstan travels through the Caspian Pipeline Consortium (CPC) Pipeline to the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossiisk. Chevron has the biggest investment. Exxon, Shell and Eni also have investments. These companies, plus Russian and Kazakh companies, own the Kazakh oil fields that are linked by the pipeline.
Only two shipments of Brazilian crude oil (260,000 tons) were exported indirectly to Israel since its invasion of Gaza. It was done with the cooperation of Shell, TotalEnergies and Petrobras, a Brazilian company. Compared with certain other countries, Brazil's ability to impose an embargo should be relatively easy, assuming Brazil's President Lula, unlike Turkey's President Erdogan, is willing to make good on his criticism of Israel.
Israel also receives small yet constant amounts of crude oil coming from Iraq, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE through Egypt where it is shipped from Alexandria. Russia also continues to send a regular supply of vacuum gas oil to a refinery in Haifa for being upgraded into gasoline and diesel fuel.
The Holocaust of the Palestinians, thus, is not merely an Israeli responsibility. It is the responsibility of the family of oil producing and transporting nations as a whole. It is, in the truest sense of the word, a family affair.

Returning to Paris, France üá´üá∑ for the Invest in African Energy Forum. The Forum opens new pathways for collaboration between international and African stakeholders. It brings together African energy ministers, heads of National Oil Companies and keystakeholders from the continent ‚Äì including #Gabon, #Nigeria, #EquatorialGuinea, the Republic of the Congo and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, as well as #Senegal, The #Gambia, #Mozambique, #SouthAfrica, #Nigeria, #Ghana and the #IvoryCoast‚Äì and independents with their international counterparts to foster growth and deal-making opportunities. 
Africa's energy sector is a vibrant frontier, offering significant untapped potential. With over 125 billion barrels of proven oil reserves, 620 trillion cubic feet of natural gas and abundant renewable energy resources ¬¨‚Äì the continent presents lucrative opportunities for foreign investors. IAE 2024 is a prime occasion to capitalize on these prospects.
Leading companies like TotalEnergies , UTM OFFSHORE LIMITED , Eni , Afentra PLC , ExxonMobil , Chariot Limited , SNPC ADNOC Group QatarEnergy Perenco , Technip Energies , Panoro Energy Groupe PETROSEN African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) and SLB are spearheading transformative projects across Africa, spanning oil, gas and renewable energy. By attending IAE 2024, you can forge strategic partnerships and innovative collaborations in the region.
Namibia, experiencing significant exploration growth in the Orange Basin with companies such as Shell, TotalEnergies, Chevron, and Galp. The country plans to leverage new oil and gas discoveries to drive investment and stimulate economic growth ¬¨‚Äì with the aim to begin oil production by 2030.
Other regions can follow Namibia's example, and IAE 2024 is the perfect place to have these discussions and for driving investment across Africa. 
Africa represents the next frontier for upstream drilling owing largely to the continent‚Äôs pipeline of high impact wells. In 2023, approximately 132 exploration wells were drilled while in 2024 and 2025, 120 wells and 123 wells are expected to be drilled, respectively.
The continent represents the final frontier in energy, teeming with untapped potential that calls for both new investments and strategic collaboration. Join us for two days of engagement, networking, business-to-business matchmaking, and in-depth investor country spotlights at this prestigious event.
Your involvement will help shape the future of Africa's energy sector and drive sustainable development across the continent. I wholeheartedly encourage you to participate in this transformative event and join us in shaping a prosperous and energy-secure future for Africa.

How much do stock buybacks matter? 
How does it work? 
Here's the lowdown in simple terms üëá
-Buybacks is effectively when a company uses cash to buy back its own shares on the open market
-It reduces total number of shares outstanding
-And your slice of the company gets bigger ‚¨ÜÔ∏è
For example:
-Company has $100 million in cash
-10 million shares outstanding
->Each share worth $10 (100m/10m)
If company does $20m buyback:
-2 million shares removed
-Now 8 million shares left
-Same $100m company value
->So each share now worth $12.50 (100m/8m)
Why do buybacks?
‚úîÔ∏èBullish signal - company thinks stock is undervalued
‚úîÔ∏èIncreases earnings per share
‚úîÔ∏èOffset dilution from executive compensation
But watch out: 
üö© Taking on debt to do buybacks is risky 
üö© Buybacks instead of investing for future growth 
üö© Inflating earnings per share artificially
‚è©The conclusion? 
Stock buybacks can be a good thing when a company genuinely believes its shares are undervalued and the buyback is funded by excess cash.
But they can also be a bad sign especially if a company is taking on debt to pursue buybacks instead of investing in future growth.
Companies you know that have been actively buying back shares over recent years:
-Apple Inc. ( $AAPL)

$GALP.PL $SEI.V $RIG $VAL $TDW $NE $TTE $XLE "Mopane: Offshore E&P Flexing its Muscles"
(1) After headline discoveries in Namibia by $TTE (Venus) and $SHEL (Graff), Galp‚Äôs Mopane exploration wells have been one of the key industry watches of 2024 since it announced the contracting of $SFL Hercules drilling rig in May 2023. While current Galp management has been tight lipped and professional, a FORMER Galp executive publicly stated he believed PEL 83 was the best ‚ÄúZIP code‚Äù in Namibia partly due to shallower water depth (~2,000m) than peers.
Last Sunday, Galp announced outstanding Mopane results of (1) >10 billion barrels of oil equivalent and (2) flows reaching ‚Äúmaximum allowed limits‚Äù during the well test. Without any further exploration success, I believe this translates to an eventual ~400k bpd oil development (~5 years to first oil). The development cost may be ~$25B, but with IRR‚Äôs comfortably >20% at $70 Brent. For the sake of comparison, $PXD Pioneer Natural Resources produced 372k barrels of oil per day (715k boepd) in 2023.
(2) Mopane ~400k bpd Capacity? Galp announced success hitting multiple layers of ‚Äúsignificant light oil columns‚Äù at Mopane-1 and Mopane-2 with ‚Äúgood porosities, high pressures and high permeabilities.‚Äù ExxonMobil‚Äôs Liza-1 and Liza-2 wells in Guyana‚Äôs Stabroek Block were drilled 8 km apart, a similar distance between Mopane-1 and Mopane-2. Today, Liza Phase 1 (~150k bpd) and Liza Phase 2 (~250k bpd) produce ~400k bpd in Guyana.
(3) Galp is rumored to be interested in drilling up to an additional 10 exploration and appraisal wells in PEL 83. As noted below, PEL 83 has additional prospects (Source: Sintana Energy, 4.9% interest in PEL 83). While offshore exploration is inherently risky, Total and Shell had oil discoveries beyond Venus and Graff in their respective blocks. Also, Galp publicly disclosed a ‚Äúnear-term‚Äù drilling plan to further explore and appraise the Mopane complex. Given the other identified targets and the Mopane success, I believe another discovery of ~150k bpd capacity potential is probable (my Base Case) although would not be explored until 2025.
(4) Long-Term Leading Indicator of Floater and OSV Demand: Exploration success in Namibia is very likely to lead to strong, durable demand growth for floaters and OSV‚Äôs. The demand growth should be gradual given deepwater‚Äôs long-cycle nature, but especially strong from 2026-2032. Shortly after Galp‚Äôs Mopane discovery announcement, Rhino Resources hired Noble‚Äôs Venturer drillship to drill two wells in their block. Additionally, Chevron will likely begin exploration drilling in PEL 90 in late 2024. Further, Upstream reported $TTE is rumored to target a 180k bpd capacity FPSO for likely Venus development (Phase 1?).
$RIG $VAL $TDW $ODL.OL $NE $SDRL $DO In 2023, a test of my confidence in the offshore thesis was future exploration drilling in Namibia. The deepwater floater market is trending positively, but needs to clear a modest amount sidelined drillship capacity. In order to get to longer term leading edge dayrates of $600k, it needs incremental demand growth from exploration success and we're currently seeing it in Namibia, as well as other countries.

$NOL.OL $TTE $RIG $SHEL $VAL $ODL.OL $SDRL Deepwater M&A Prospect, "Good Assets, Bad Balance Sheet" 
(1) Northern Ocean (‚ÄúNOL‚Äù) was created to purchase two stranded newbuild UDW HE Semisubs, Deepsea Mira and Deepsea Bollsta in 2018-2019. Both meet Norway's high standards and are marketable across the world. Despite recent stronger market conditions for UDW HE Semisubs compared to Drillships, NOL‚Äôs balance sheet, near-term maturities, liquidity and uncontracted ‚Äúwhite space‚Äù have contributed to NOL‚Äôs financial vulnerability that has dragged its equity performance lower in 2024. Both Mira and Bollsta are high spec rigs with similar designs to RIG's Norge and Odjfell‚Äôs Deepsea Nordkapp UDW HE Semisubs. At 4/19/23 valuations, NOL is $329mm per UDW HE Semisub rig compared to an estimated ~$1B newbuild cost per rig. UDW HE Semisub pure-play $ODL.OL is +30.7% YTD, while $NOL.OL is -13.3% YTD. Odfjell‚Äôs semisubs are 100% contracted for years to come, while Northern Ocean‚Äôs semisubs are uncontracted in 2025.
(2) NOL an M&A Target? $TTE acquired 75% of the Tungsten Explorer drillship in February 2024 from a financially vulnerable Vantage Drilling as an innovative step to control costs. Considering Mira and Bollsta are working in Namibia, Total may be interested for Venus discovery but is likely a low bid. Odfjell Drilling may be an interested acquirer as they manage both Mira and Bollsta, although do not present an obvious cash solution for NOL's $390mm of bank debt due in January 2025. $RIG stated they would use proceeds from their recent $1.8B bond offering to tender outstanding debt, although have cash remaining after their initial tender offers. Transocean ‚Äúkicked the tires‚Äù on Bollsta in 2017, though chose not to purchase due to additional capital investment needs and the mobilization fee. Northern Ocean eventually acquired Bollsta and was delivered in June 2019.
(3) Hemen Holding, indirectly controlled by John Fredriksen, owns 39% of NOL. Also, a related entity Sterna has loaned $151mm to NOL to support their liquidity. The majority of NOL‚Äôs $54mm cash at 12/31/2023 is likely to go toward the upcoming SPS for Deepsea Bollsta when its contract with Shell concludes this June. Further straining NOL‚Äôs liquidity, its $390mm term loans are floating rate. SOFR rising 500 bps in the last 24 months has contributed to nearly $20mm/year in higher interest costs.
(4) Mira and Bollsta are both located in Namibia where there has been substantial deepwater exploration success. While Total and Shell appear likely toward developing, Galp Energia‚Äôs recent success in PEL 83 with Mopane-1 and Mopane-2 exploration wells likely indicates future demand from them, as well as Chevron likely embarking on an exploration campaign in PEL 90 within the next 12 months. When SFL‚Äôs Hercules leaves for Canada, Namibia will only have 3 deepwater rigs, an amount that could reasonably double or triple in coming years.

Unmasking Fossil Fuel Disinformation: Top 5 Tactics Exposed" highlights the sophisticated and well-funded disinformation campaigns orchestrated by the fossil fuel industry to cast doubt on climate change and delay meaningful action. The Guardian and other sources have recently shared insights into these tactics, aiming to help the public and journalists navigate the climate change discussion more effectively.
Here are the top 5 tactics:
Amplifying Uncertainty: Fossil fuel companies often emphasize the uncertainties in climate science, even though the scientific consensus is overwhelmingly clear. This tactic aims to create doubt and confusion among the public.
Promoting False Solutions: The industry frequently promotes "solutions" that do not address the root causes of climate change, such as carbon capture and storage, while downplaying the importance of reducing fossil fuel consumption.
Funding Opposition: The fossil fuel industry funds organizations and individuals who oppose climate action, providing them with resources to spread their message. This includes think tanks, advocacy groups, and even some politicians.
Greenwashing: Companies engage in "greenwashing" by promoting their efforts to reduce emissions or invest in renewable energy, while continuing to expand fossil fuel production. This creates a misleading image of their environmental commitment.
Targeting Vulnerable Communities: The industry often targets low-income and minority communities with disinformation campaigns, exploiting their economic vulnerability to gain support for fossil fuel projects.
To spot these tactics, it's essential to be aware of the sources of information and their potential biases. It's also important to critically evaluate the claims made and look for evidence to support them. By understanding these tactics, we can better navigate the disinformation landscape and make informed decisions about climate change and the actions needed to address it.

BREAKING NEWS
The state of mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures in the oil and gas industry reflects a dynamic landscape influenced by various factors both globally and within the United States. In the upstream segment, oil and gas majors have been actively pursuing acquisitions, with notable players like Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and Occidental Petroleum leading the charge. These acquisitions, which accounted for a significant portion of total deal value in the energy, natural resources, and chemicals sectors, have primarily focused on securing assets in strategic locations such as West Texas, North Dakota, and Guyana's coast. The midstream and downstream segments are witnessing a mix of consolidation and strategic divestments, particularly in response to evolving market dynamics and regulatory shifts. Mergers and acquisition deals, however, face hurdles due to valuation gaps and uncertainties surrounding capital returns from existing investments.
Globally, the oil market outlook is characterized by cautious optimism amid ongoing OPEC+ production cuts, leading to reduced forecasts for global oil production growth in 2024. This reduction in growth, coupled with falling inventories, is expected to drive up Brent crude oil spot prices. In the United States, retail gasoline prices are projected to rise, largely driven by higher crude oil prices, while natural gas prices are expected to remain relatively low.
On Monday, April 15, 2024, I will be joining with the Federal Reserve Bank and leading experts in energy and finance to discuss insights about the unfolding dynamics and the transaction opportunities they present.

VENEZUELA - THE RISE & FALL
Venezuela, home to the world‚Äôs largest oil reserves, is a case study in the perils of becoming a petrostate. Since it was discovered in the country in the 1920s, oil has taken Venezuela on an exhilarating but dangerous boom-and-bust ride that offers lessons for other resource-rich states. Decades of poor governance have driven what was once one of Latin America‚Äôs most prosperous countries to economic and political ruin.
In recent years, Venezuela has suffered economic collapse, with output shrinking significantly and rampant hyperinflation contributing to a scarcity of basic goods, such as food and medicine. Meanwhile, government mismanagement and U.S. sanctions have led to a drastic decline in oil production and severe underinvestment in the sector.
Venezuela is the archetype of a failed petrostate (Petrostate is an informal term used to describe a country where: government income is deeply reliant on the export of oil and natural gas; economic and political power are highly concentrated in an elite minority & political institutions are weak and unaccountable, and corruption is widespread). 
A number of grim indicators tell the story:
- Oil dependence: In recent years, oil exports have financed almost two-thirds of the government‚Äôs budget
- Falling production: Starved of adequate investment and maintenance, oil output has continued to generally decline
- Turbulent economy: Venezuela‚Äôs gross domestic product (GDP) shrank
- Soaring debt: Venezuela has an estimated debt burden of more than $150 billion
- Hyperinflation: Annual inflation skyrocketed to just over 130,000% in 2018, and though it has since slowed, it remained at 360% in 2023
How did Venezuela get here
A number of economic and political milestones mark Venezuela‚Äôs path as a petrostate:
- Discovering oil: In 1922, Royal Dutch Shell geologists at La Rosa, a field in the Maracaibo Basin, struck oil, which blew out at what was then an extraordinary rate of one hundred thousand barrels per day. In a matter of years, more than one hundred foreign companies were producing oil, backed by dictator General Juan Vicente G√≥mez (1908‚Äì1935). Annual production exploded during the 1920s from just over a million barrels to 137 million, making Venezuela second only to the United States in total output by 1929. By the time G√≥mez died in 1935, Dutch disease had settled in: the Venezuelan bol√≠var had ballooned, and oil shoved aside other sectors to account for over 90% of total exports
- Reclaiming oil rents: By the 1930s, just three foreign companies - Gulf, Royal Dutch Shell & Standard Oil - controlled 98% of the Venezuelan oil market. G√≥mez‚Äôs successors sought to reform the oil sector to funnel funds into government coffers. The Hydrocarbons Law (requiring foreign companies to give half of their oil profits to the state) of 1943 was the first step in that direction
- Punto Fijo pact: In 1958, after a succession of military dictatorships, Venezuela elected its first stable democratic government. That year, Venezuela‚Äôs three major political parties signed the Punto Fijo pact (which guaranteed that state jobs and, notably, oil rents would be parcelled out to the three parties in proportion to voting results). While the pact sought to guard against dictatorship and usher in democratic stability, it ensured that oil profits would be concentrated in the state
- The 1970s boom: In 1973, a five-month OPEC embargo on countries backing Israel in the Yom Kippur War quadrupled oil prices and made Venezuela the country with the highest per-capita income in Latin America
- The 1980s oil glut: As global oil prices plummeted in the 1980s, Venezuela‚Äôs economy contracted and inflation soared; at the same time, it accrued massive foreign debt by purchasing foreign refineries (such as Citgo in the United States)
- Ch√°vez‚Äôs Bolivarian revolution: Ch√°vez was elected president in 1998 on a socialist platform, pledging to use Venezuela‚Äôs vast oil wealth to reduce poverty and inequality. While his costly ‚ÄúBolivarian missions‚Äù expanded social services and cut poverty by 20%, he also took several steps that precipitated a long and steady decline in the country‚Äôs oil production, which peaked in the late 1990s and early 2000s
- Descent into dictatorship: In mid-2014, global oil prices tumbled and Venezuela‚Äôs economy went into free fall. As unrest brewed, Maduro consolidated power through political repression, censorship, and electoral manipulation. In 2018, he secured re-election in a race widely condemned as unfair and undemocratic
The impact of U.S. sanctions
For almost two decades, Washington has imposed sweeping sanctions against Caracas, the most significant of which have blocked oil imports & prevented the government from accessing the U.S. financial system. In November 2022, in part to help offset rising global energy prices due to the war in Ukraine, the United States permitted U.S. oil giant Chevron to resume limited operations in the country. In exchange, the Maduro government and the opposition agreed to continue dialogue following a yearlong stalemate. The following October, Caracas agreed to a roadmap for a free and fair presidential election in 2024. Washington rewarded the move by further easing sanctions on Venezuela‚Äôs oil and gas sector, allowing it to export oil and gas products for six months But the government‚Äôs failure to meet conditions for a fair vote ...

putting oil thieves and vandals on the defensive across various parts of the Niger Delta, from Bayelsa to Ondo to Rivers to Akwa Ibom States, and beyond, with the recovery of massive quantities of stolen products, the dismantling of discovered sites, and arrest of suspects.

Chatham House: Elusive Transparency and Private Interests
Chatham House, also known as the Royal Institute of International Affairs, is a British think tank based in London, England. It was founded in 1920 and is dedicated to the study of international affairs. Chatham House's mission is to help governments and societies build a sustainably secure, prosperous, and just world. The organization is known for its independent analysis, trusted dialogue, and influential ideas.
Chatham House is the originator of the Chatham House Rule, which is a principle for holding debates and discussions under a rule that allows participants to use the information received, but without revealing the identity or affiliation of the speaker. This rule is intended to promote open and honest discussions on important issues.
The think tank has been involved in various research and events related to global issues, including climate change, international security, and global development. For example, they hosted an event where the Executive Secretary of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) spoke about the actions needed to address climate change.
Chatham House is a membership-based organization that includes individuals, organizations, and corporations. Members have access to a range of benefits, including invitations to events, access to research publications, and opportunities to engage in discussions with experts in international affairs.
The organization has a rich history and has played a significant role in shaping global discourse on international relations. It continues to be a leading voice in the field of international affairs, providing analysis and ideas to help address global challenges.
The Founding
The Royal Institute of International Affairs, known as Chatham House, was established in 1920. It received the Grade-I listed 18th-century building, Chatham House, as a gift in 1923. The Chatham House Rule, which is a principle for holding debates and discussions under a rule that allows participants to use the information received, but without revealing the identity or affiliation of the speaker, was created in June 1927. The rule was later modified in 1992 and 2002.
Who founded Chatham House?
The Royal Institute of International Affairs, commonly known as Chatham House, was founded in 1920. It was founded by a group of individuals, primarily by Lionel Curtis, with assistance from individuals like Lord Robert Cecil and members of the British Foreign Office.
Lionel Curtis
Lionel George Curtis (1872‚Äì1955) was a British public administrator, author, and advocate of British imperial federalism and a world state. He was born in Little Eaton, Derbyshire, England, on March 7, 1872. Curtis played a significant role in the development of the Commonwealth of Nations and had considerable influence on international politics.
In 1910, Curtis founded the Round Table, a quarterly journal, to propagate his ideas about Liberal imperialism. He was appointed Beit lecturer in colonial history at the University of Oxford in 1912, and in 1920, he helped found the organization that became the Royal Institute of International Affairs, commonly known as Chatham House.
 He authored several books, including "The Commonwealth of Nations" (1916), "Dyarchy" (1920), and "Civitas Dei: The Commonwealth of God" (1938). In "Civitas Dei," Curtis argued that the United States should rejoin the British Commonwealth and that the Commonwealth should evolve into a world government.
Lord Robert Cecil 
Lord Robert Cecil, also known as the 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, CH, PC, QC (14 September 1864 ‚Äì 24 November 1958), was a British lawyer, politician, and diplomat. He is best known for his role as one of the architects of the League of Nations.
His efforts in promoting international peace and cooperation were recognized when he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1937.
Lord Robert Cecil was born as Edgar Algernon Robert Gascoyne-Cecil in London, England. He was educated at University College, Oxford, where he became well known for his debating skills. In 1887, he was admitted to the Bar and practiced as a barrister until 1906. He was appointed as a Queen's Counsel in 1899.
League of Nations
The League of Nations was an international organization established after World War I with the aim to prevent future wars and promote international cooperation. It was founded in 1920 as a result of the Paris Peace Conference, which was convened to negotiate peace treaties following the First World War. The League's founding members included 42 countries, with notable absences being the United States, which did not ratify the Treaty of Versailles, and Germany, which was initially excluded but later joined in 1926.
Despite its noble intentions and some significant achievements, the League of Nations ultimately failed in its primary goal to prevent another world war. It was unable to prevent the aggression of Italy, Germany, and Japan in the late 1930s, which eventually led to the outbreak of World War II. 
The League of Nations was officially dissolved in April 1946, and its functions and responsibilities were transferred to the newly formed United Nations. 
The League of Nations, established after World War I, was a precursor to several modern international organizations like NATO, the UN, and the WEF.
Round Table Movement
The Round Table Movement was a political organization founded in 1909 with the aim of strengthening the British Empire by promoting closer union among Britain and its self-governing colonies, such as Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa. It was particularly active in imperial affairs during the early 20th century. The movement was conceived as a means to ensure the continued unity and strength of the British Empire while also encouraging the development of a "Commonwealth of free 'British' nations."
The Round Table Movement was inspired by the ideas of Cecil Rhodes and Lord Milner, who were key figures in British imperial policy at the time. They envisioned a global network of political elites working towards a unified Anglo-Saxon political and economic order. 
The Round Table Movement was instrumental in the establishment of two influential think tanks: Chatham House in London and the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. 
The Council on Foreign Relations
The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) is an independent, nonpartisan think tank and publisher dedicated to promoting understanding of international relations and foreign policy. It was founded in 1921 and is headquartered in New York City. 
Chatham House Presidents
Baroness Manningham-Buller LG DCB: Director-General of the UK Security Service (MI5) between 2002 and 2007 and became an independent life peer in 2008. She served as Chairman of the Council of Imperial College London from 2011 to 2015. She was a member of the Board of Governors of the Wellcome Trust from 2008 to 2021 and Chair of the Wellcome Trust‚Äôs Board of Governors from 2015 to 2021.
Mark Carney: an economist and banker who served as the governor of the Bank of England from 2013 to 2020, and prior to that as governor of the Bank of Canada from 2008 until 2013. He was chairman of the Financial Stability Board from 2011 to 2018. Prior to his governorships, Mr. Carney worked at Goldman Sachs as well as the Canadian Department of Finance.
The Rt Hon Helen Clark: was prime minister of New Zealand from 1999-2008. She then became the 8th and first female administrator of the UN Development Programme, completing two terms from 2009-2017. 
She currently chairs the Independent Panel for Pandemic Preparedness and Response with former president of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, which was convened by the World Health Organization in 2020. 
The Rt Hon Sir John Major KG CH: served in the Government for sixteen years joining the Cabinet in 1987 as Chief Secretary to the Treasury. In July 1989 he was appointed Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, a position he held for 94 days before being appointed Chancellor of the Exchequer in October of that year. Sir John became Prime Minister in November 1990, and led the Conservative Party to an unprecedented fourth term in Office at the General Election in April 1992.

When nations struck a historic deal to phase out fossil fuels last fall, then-U.S. climate envoy John F. Kerry was elated.
‚ÄúWe are moving away from fossil fuels ‚Äî and we are not turning back,‚Äù Kerry declared at the U.N. Climate Change Conference in Dubai.
But three months later, it appears that some of the world‚Äôs biggest oil and gas companies did not get the memo. At an energy conference here this week, their leaders struck a much different tone, predicting that fossil fuels will continue to power the global economy well into the future.
‚ÄúWe should abandon the fantasy of phasing out oil and gas,‚Äù Amin Nasser, president and CEO of Saudi Aramco, said to applause at CERAWeek by S&P Global.
Shell CEO Wael Sawan declared that ‚Äúthere is going to be a multidimensional energy system in the future, [and] oil and gas will continue to have an important role in stabilizing that system for a long, long, long time to come.‚Äù
And Patrick Pouyann√©, CEO of the French energy giant TotalEnergies, said he was ‚Äúquite pleased‚Äù that the Dubai deal recognized ‚Äúthat we need some transition fuels, and gas is one of them.‚Äù
It‚Äôs hardly surprising that oil industry executives would see a continued role for their products, even as the world shifts to cleaner fuels to fight climate change. But their remarks underscored an uncomfortable reality for climate advocates and policymakers globally: Demand for oil keeps rising, delaying the end of the fossil fuel era.
The industry executives‚Äô pronouncements are backed up by record oil-and-gas production and consumer misgivings over purchasing electric vehicles. At the same time, utilities are rushing to line up more natural gas to meet explosive power demand fueled by electricity-hungry data centers.
President Biden‚Äôs top climate officials face another uncomfortable fact: The United States is now pumping more oil than any other country in history. U.S. crude oil production averaged 12.9 million barrels per day in 2023, breaking the previous record of 12.3 million barrels per day set in 2019.
Big Oil and its investors are reaping the rewards. ExxonMobil and Chevron, the largest U.S. energy companies, reported their biggest annual profits in a decade last year. Exxon reported $36 billion in earnings, while Chevron netted $21.4 billion.
Nasser projected that global oil demand will reach a new record of 104 million barrels per day this year, despite the growth of electric vehicles and wind and solar energy. He rejected the International Energy Agency‚Äôs forecast that oil consumption will peak in 2030. (The coalition of oil-producing nations led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, known as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, has also criticized the IEA‚Äôs forecast as unrealistic.)

$GALP $RIG $TDW $VAL $TTE $SHEL $SEI.V $ODL.OL Deepwater Update, March 9, 2024. "Beyond Guyana: Namibia's Harsher Waters More Rich in Oil?"
(1) $CVX $53B acquisition of $HES in October 2023, which includes Hess‚Äô crucial 30% stake in Guyana‚Äôs offshore Stabroek Block, is contested by incumbent $XOM, citing a right of first refusal in the Stabroek block joint operating agreement. Chevron/Hess argue their merger‚Äôs structure makes Exxon‚Äôs claim irrelevant. This fight between oil majors for the right to invest tens of billions of dollars in Guyana signifies substantial value, although recent major oil discoveries in Namibia rival those found in Guyana.
(2) Namibia‚Äôs ‚ÄúSkeleton Coast‚Äù: The Benguela Current contributes to difficult conditions in Namibia for ships due to dense fog and strong currents, leading to reduced visibility and navigational challenges that have historically resulted in numerous shipwrecks along the Skeleton Coast‚Äôs inhospitable shoreline. The unfriendly seas of Namibia previously prioritized other parts of the world for deepwater exploration, although 3D seismic and special rigs designed for harsh Norwegian North Sea conditions have helped Namibia become the global hotspot for oil exploration.
(3) Deepwater Guyana is a benign offshore market where drillships are best designed to work. Due to the harsh Benguela current, Namibia is ‚Äúharsh environment‚Äù offshore waters where drillships are less capable. Harsh Environment (‚ÄúHE‚Äù) Semisubs were designed to work in the rough waters of Norway, although as global offshore oil exploration has expended in recent years, the HE Semisubs have played a key role in exploration drilling the ultradeep harsh waters of Namibia. 
Substantial discoveries in the Namibian Orange Basin by TotalEnergies (Venus), Shell (Graff) and now Galp (Mopane) have drawn comparisons to Guyana‚Äôs Stabroek block, with future exploration activity potentially making Namibia even larger. Comments from two major global oil company executives thus far include, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs massive‚Äù and the oil flows ‚Äúlike a train.‚Äù While Total, Shell and Galp appear headed toward developing their separate blocks, Chevron, Woodside and others have yet to drill their first exploration well.
(4) After initial discovery in 2016, current resource estimates in Guyana are >11 Billion BOE (Source: Hess). While discoveries in Namibia took until 2022-2023 to be found, TotalEnergies‚Äô and Shell‚Äôs resources are likely 3-5 Billion BOE to date (very unofficial, rough estimate) with substantial exploration still to come. Little known Portuguese oil company Galp Energia is engaged in the most exciting current exploration campaign in PEL 83. In January, Galp‚Äôs Mopane-1X well encountered ‚Äútwo significant light oil columns.‚Äù Galp‚Äôs Mopane-2X well is currently being drilled with results likely announced in a few weeks. Surrounded by oil giants in Namibia, depending on exploration results Galp may be the Hess of Namibia and will likely have to find a partner for its 80% interest in PEL 83. Chevron is expected to begin exploring PEL 90 in the next 12 months with Australian Woodside to do the same on the ‚ÄúSaturn Superfan‚Äù in PEL 87 in 2025. Sintana Energy owns minority interests in PEL 83, PEL 90 and PEL 87 and provides the Namibia exploration map to the left that I have borrowed 4 times now.

Don‚Äôt hoard $400m funding opportunities from ordinary Nigerians, Sen @NatashaAkpoti tells NCDMB
Lawmaker representing Kogi Central and the Chairman, Senate Committee on Local Content, Senator Natasha Akpoti-Uduaghan has charged Nigerian Content Development and Monitoring Board (NCDMB) to make funding opportunities accessible to ordinary Nigerians while uncovering $400m intervention funds domiciled in some financial institutions for couple of years.
Out of the intervention funds uncovered, $50m was budgeted for capacity building in oil and gas ($30m) and women in oil and gas businesses ($20m), respectively.
Another $50m of Local content development fund available for Research and Development in oil and gas industries was also domiciled in Central Bank of Nigeria.
These funds, according to her, will attract oil and gas equipment manufacturers to NOGaPS facilities, as well as increase access to affordable finance by the manufacturing entities, adding that the board should explain to Nigerians who are not aware of the availability of the fund how they can access it. 
The Local Content Chairman during her interactive session with management of NCDMB on Wednesday, specifically lamented that while Chevron apart from crude oil exploration in Saudi Arabia, also manufactures Polypropylene (one of the waste products from Gas) to produce Syringe which fetches Saudi Arabia $6billion annually.
She further blamed the collapse of Jubilee Syringe Plant in Bayelsa on the lacuna in the operational model of the International Oil companies.
As part of its oversight functions, the committee mandated the management to submit the audited account of NCDMB from 2021 to 2022, the budgetary performances of 2022 and 2023, and the nominal roll of the Board. 
In his remarks, the Executive Secretary of NCDMB, Engr Felix Ogbo revealed that 300 million dollars meant for Nigeria Content Intervention Fund is still domiciled in Bank of Industry.
According to the board, the entire 300 million dollars has been disbursed. The board added that the total amount disbursed so far amounts to 330 million dollars, explaining that as beneficiaries pay, the money would be given to others who want to borrow.
The management added that five companies out of the seventy companies that accessed the fund have fully repaid the loan and it has been efficient and successful. 
The management disclosed that the only challenge was during COVID-19 when there was a global economic shutdown and the board interacted with the BoI managing the fund, to give the companies palliative of two years moratorium to enable companies recover from the effect of the pandemic.
"Bank of Industry carries out quarterly monitoring to ensure the companies use the loan for the purpose it was meant for. We also carry out joint annual project monitoring with the Bank of Industry," Ogbo said. 
Senator Natasha, however, noted that the oil and gas sector cannot work in isolation of other sectors, calling for synergy amongst them. 
She tasked the management of the board to interact with the international oil companies operating in Nigeria on how to establish manufacturing companies in the country through the use of byproduct of gas like polypropylene for the manufacturing of syringe, protective wares and other products instead of making Nigeria just extracting hub. 
"I am glad that quite a number of various committee chairmen were here, and everyone is all passionate and committed on the same goal to grow Nigeria, to grow capacity in product and services that will support not only the oil and gas but in turn other critical sectors that will be stimulated.
‚ÄùWe cannot just allow the oil companies to turn Nigeria into just an extractive zone as far as exploration of crude oil is concerned but a manufacturing one as well with attendant economic value.

The only time I saw Eddison Zvobgo in the flesh I was on my way to Rezende Bus Terminus to catch a bus home on a busy Friday afternoon in 1992. His black ministerial Mercedes Benz was parked near Kingston Bookshop along Kwame Nkrumah Avenue. The late Masvingo Zanu-PF kingpin looked dapper and sharp and larger than life as he puffed on a cigarette by the pavement.
I was surprised to see him appear cool and calm and collected in a public spot. Cabinet ministers breathed rarefied air back then and lived aloof from the very people whose lives depended on their actions and decisions. However I had heard that Minister Zvobgo loved to meet and talk with commoners at Chevron Hotel in Masvingo. So I had one million questions for him that day. And yet for all my juvenile ambition I was awed by his presence and mindful of two mean-looking bodyguards near him ‚Äì so much so ‚Äì I hesitated and walked on when presented with half a chance to pick his famed intellectual brains.
But that was the real problem. I had buckled under the strain of built-up anxiety and fear and remained crushed and dwarfed by the bizarrely false independence-era belief that you cannot hobnob with Cabinet ministers and ask them difficult questions about critical national matters. I simply wanted to know why Minister Zvobgo had crafted the executive presidency.
But even before that constitutional disaster came along Zimbabwe had been a very fearsome and inhibitory society. I remember how I often spent holidays at Kamativi Tin Mine in Matabeleland North. My aunt Resca worked as a nurse at the mine hospital and enjoyed inviting family members over. I had wonderful friends in Kamativi. Like Munyaradzi: his mother hailed from Mashonaland while his father was Ndebele. Munyaradzi and I really had fun. We would play at the mine compound and shops and wander around aimlessly each and every day.
Whenever Munyaradzi was not around I used to get around the mine on my own speaking a combination of English and Shona without a problem at all. I really loved the place. I really loved the people. And I really loved the journey from Harare to Kamativi ‚Äì especially when I took the train to Bulawayo along with my elder niece ‚Äì since I enjoyed drinking coffee and eating snacks on the train. Uncharacteristically I also loved the bus ride from Bulawayo to Kamativi and treasured passing through places like Lupane district.
It was all so lovely and normal and tranquil and the mine itself was a beautiful labour of construction. My aunt Resca had a nice little company house which was located on a small hill near the shops. She stayed in Kamativi for so long my youngest niece learnt to speak fluent Ndebele. Later she would marry a Ndebele man and open up a whole new world for us all and our Ndebele in-laws.
I have nonetheless never been able to view my brother-in-law through ethnic eyes. I have never been to label my friends using regional locations. I have never put any credence to where they were born and the languages they speak. I have also learnt to avoid the discriminatory friends I had in the past and maintain very few fair-minded acquaintances.
Because while I was young and enjoying my childhood in Kamativi ‚Äì Gukurahundi was well underway in parts of Matabeleland. All the while nobody ever treated me badly in Kamativi. Nobody threatened me. Nobody hurt me. Nobody made me feel unwelcome. I was treated like any other child and never felt unloved and unwanted wherever I went. I would not have spent so many holidays there were that not the case. So how was I to know about cruel civilian deaths elsewhere when there was a total media blackout on the deadly matter?
But when I was older and knew better and the Internet came alive I downloaded a report on the Catholic Church investigation into Gukurahundi. It is such a graphic and horrific report of the brutal terror that the Perence Shiri-led Fifth Brigade carried out reading it sends shivers up and down one‚Äôs spine. Tribal-based animosity and conflict did not however end when the horrendous hostilities ceased and the Unity Accord was signed in 1987. In the aftermath of the low-level war many Shona racists have found fertile grounds to continually sow the seeds of tribalism in Zimbabwe.
I have heard a lot of inane fallacies about how and why Gukurahundi happened. I have heard seemingly normal and rational people routinely infer that the Ndebele people caused Gukurahundi and deserved to suffer and die for it. I have heard incredibly reckless statements about how Ndebele people pretend not to speak Shona. Yet I have so many excellent friends who happen to be Ndebele and have never expected them to speak Shona. They are my friends and not language experts and I do not speak Ndebele anyway. Maybe if I had learnt Ndebele alongside Shona at school I would speak several languages now.
I do not tolerate prejudice in any context and consciously avoid people who are racial bigots. I appreciate all manner of people and work hard to maintain a healthy mind and transparent approach towards cultural diversity. I have in-laws who are Zulu and that too has been a wonderful experience.
So I would have loved to know what the Harvard-trained Zvobgo thought about Gukurahundi. Did he have a legal opinion and personal position on the awful tragedy? Did he believe that military officials should face prosecution for the tragedy? Did he believe in the establishment of a truth and reconciliation and compensation process for the victims of Gukurahundi and their loved ones? I feel for the people who lost family and friends in utterly inhumane circumstances. Zimbabwe must reach out and let them know that all broadminded humanitarians feel their pain still.
Which is why Zimbabwe should offer an unreserved and wholehearted apology to the affected families and Matabeleland regions. I hope that the unreasonable fear that flourishes in social and political spaces will perish forever. I also hope that contemporary divisions between regular people and wealthy elected representatives will somehow be substituted with confidence-building actions and accountability and profound prosperity for all. I truthfully hope for an equal society where nobody from Matabeleland feels foreign and left out because of historic injustices and social and economic discrimination.
I cannot remember when I made my final journey to Kamativi. But I remember the warmth and sunshine that overwhelmed the small mining town like I was there yesterday. Low tin prices led to the closure of the mine in 1994. Yet the humble and wonderful people in Kamativi had opened my world to the abundant richness of common humanity. Zimbabwe must have a million melting pots like Kamativi. Places where real unity rises above politics and public posturing. Places where people relish a multicultural society and care for each other without callous expectation of mainstream recognition or a round of public applause. Places that you and I will always feel happy and proud to call home.

Ten senators, including those on critical committees involved in climate regulations, own between $403,023 and $1,201,000 in individual stocks of Big Oil companies, according to a database of personal financial disclosure reports maintained and analyzed by CREW. The vast majority‚Äîup to $1,106,000‚Äîof the Big Oil stock held by senators is held by Republicans.¬†
Five of the ten senators who hold Big Oil stocks sit on committees tasked with environmental protection, climate issues and oversight of the agencies responsible for addressing the climate crisis.¬†
While sitting on committees tasked with environmental protection or the climate makes the conflict of interest inherent in holding Big Oil stock as a U.S. senator more glaring, every senator has opportunities to vote on legislation that impacts Big Oil profits. For example, nine out of the ten senators who hold Big Oil stock voted on last summer‚Äôs Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which the White House calls ‚Äúthe most significant action Congress has taken on clean energy and climate change in the nation‚Äôs history.‚Äù The bill passed along party lines.¬†
Senator Jerry Moran, a Republican from Kansas, reported holding the most Big Oil stock, with between $119,006 and $360,000 in Exxon and Chevron. Over the years, Moran has been a vocal critic of climate regulation; he voted to deny that human actions cause climate change, voted against the IRA, criticized the Green New Deal and promoted the Keystone XL fossil fuel pipeline. Moran serves on the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, which has jurisdiction over oceans, weather, climate change and natural disasters.¬†
Nebraska Republican Senator Pete Ricketts also has a large Big Oil portfolio, and his is quite diversified. Ricketts holds stock in five different companies, with between $100,001 and $254,000 in Chevron, Exxon, Phillips 66, Valero and ConocoPhillips. Ricketts was just appointed to the Senate in January 2023, but has a record of opposing climate regulations as Nebraska governor, including calling the IRA part of President Biden‚Äôs ‚Äúradical environmental agenda.‚Äù As a member of the Committee on Environment and Public Works, which has jurisdiction over environmental and anti-pollution laws and oversees the Environmental Protection Agency, Ricketts is now in a position with particular power over the fossil fuel industry.¬†
The ranking member of the Committee on Environment and Public Works, Senator Shelley Moore Capito, a Republican from West Virginia, holds between $32,004 and $130,000 in Exxon, Chevron, Shell and Phillips 66 stocks. She is also a member of the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee‚Äîputting her in the unique position of serving on both committees most relevant to Big Oil. She‚Äôs used those positions to push back on climate regulations, including recently attempting to kill an EPA clean power plan. She has also drawn scrutiny for introducing legislation that would have approved the Mountain Valley Pipeline, while owning stock in a company behind the project.¬†
Perhaps the most extreme stance on the climate crisis belongs to Senator Tommy Tuberville, a Republican from Alabama, who has expressed a belief that God controls the climate and that the climate crisis is nothing more than ‚Äúa talking point on the left that gives them an opportunity to scream and yell that this country is not going to last for 12 more years.‚Äù Tuberville has significant Big Oil stock holdings, with between $51,002 and $117,000 in Exxon, Marathon and Chevron stocks.
Not every Big Oil stock holder has been hostile to climate protections and regulations. Democratic Delaware Senator Thomas Carper holds between $3,000 and $45,000 in Chevron, Shell and TotalEnergies. Biden Stumbles Again With Green Energy Subsidies
Over the past year, US taxpayers have learned that one of the chief lessons of #Bidenomics 101 is doling out billions of dollars in green energy subsidies for wealthy corporations. This was what the trifecta of legislative accomplishments ‚Äì #Inflation Reduction Act, the CHIPS and Science Act, and the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law ‚Äì was all about. President Joe #Biden traveled to Philadelphia, PA, this weekend to again tout Bidenomics and announce several billion dollars in so-called federal investments for #hydrogen projects.
$7 Billion for Green Energy Subsidies
Stumbling twice on a short flight of stairs, President Biden took to the stage to award $7 billion in federal grants across 16 states, from #California to #Pennsylvania, for developing seven regional hydrogen hubs as part of the administration‚Äôs broader decarbonization initiative. What companies will receive some of these green energy subsidies? A range of businesses will be involved, but three of the most prominent names on the list are #Amazon, #Chevron, and #Exxon Mobil, worth a combined $2.2 trillion.
While critics would likely ask why some of the wealthiest corporations in the world need a handout from Uncle Sam, President Biden noted that the giveaway is essentially seed money to help jump-start the production of clean hydrogen by having the critical infrastructure established. Additionally, the total investment in these hubs will reach $50 billion because of the substantial private investment also being made.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to announce one of the largest advanced manufacturing investments in the history of this nation. It‚Äôs all part of my plan to make things in America,‚Äù Biden said.
Of course, the administration‚Äôs latest announcement focuses on clean energy, but observers are omitting one key thing: Green energy subsidies are just more corporate welfare. Politicians are, once again, transferring resources from taxpayers to special interests.
Is Hydrogen the Answer?
Hydrogen is considered a crucial component for achieving the world‚Äôs net zero carbon emissions objective by 2050. Hydrogen emits only water when burned as fuel or inside a fuel cell for automobiles. However, hydrogen production requires an immense volume of energy, meaning that, depending on its source, it might not be as green as its proponents would contend. So, for instance, hydrogen can be produced from natural gas, and this so-called bridge fuel has received enormous criticism from climate activists.
Consider this statement from Maggie Coulter, an attorney at the Center for Biological Diversity‚Äôs Climate Law Institute, who told the Associated Press: ‚ÄúThrowing billions at hydrogen hubs deepens our dependence on fossil fuels and worsens the climate emergency.‚Äù
Indeed, hydrogen could only be labeled green if new renewable sources are built to power hydrogen output rather than relying on the present grid and other carbon accounting programs. In other words, it might have the same environmental effects as fossil fuels. For now, according to the International Council on Clean Transportation, the world is greenwashing green hydrogen.
Trickle-Down Bidenomics
US administration officials have repeatedly asserted that Bidenomics is about growing the economy from the middle out and bottom up, abandoning the concept of trickle-down economics of the past three decades. However, this pejorative term ‚Äì economic policies that disproportionately favor Corporate America and the 1% ‚Äì can apply to the president‚Äôs economic doctrine.
As Liberty Nation has regularly reported, the White House, state governments, and city officials are spending trillions of dollars on corporate welfare. No one in the Oval Office or inside the Democratic caucus on Capitol Hill wants to admit this because the taxpayer-funded subsidies are allocated to their preferred sectors, mainly green energy.
President Biden has demanded that corporations must pay their fair share while signing over checks to these same entities. Moreover, global leaders, like United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, have called for an end to fossil fuel subsidies. This should be a welcome call to action as long as it includes renewables and green energy. Otherwise, they pick winners and losers, favor one industry over another, and engage in hypocrisy. Leftists are not opposed to corporate welfare. They just want the money to go to another set of special interests for a specific cause. That is Bidenomics 101.
This was originally published on Liberty Nation.

PRESS RELEASE:
NNPC Limited, NCDMB, IOCs SIGN MoU To Reduce Contracting Cycle
In a major boost for the nation‚Äôs oil and gas industry, the NNPC Ltd and the Nigerian Content Development & Monitoring Board (NCDMB) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the International Oil Companies (IOCs) to reduce contracting cycle to an optimal level of not more than 180 working days.
The MoU, which was executed on Monday at the NNPC Towers in Abuja, was a demonstration of NNPC Ltd‚Äôs commitment to the efficiency mandate as enshrined in the Petroleum Industry Act (PIA), which is hinged on developing an industry framework for an optimized contracting cycle.
An optimized contracting cycle is expected to improve the ease of doing business, reduce cost and drive efficiency which will eventually translate to production growth, increased revenues, and ultimately improved profitability.
The MoU is also expected to contribute significantly to the double-digit economic growth rate agenda of the Federal Government and generate tremendous value for all the stakeholders which include investors, companies, host communities and the nation at large.
Key benefits of the framework in the MoU include a reduction of the contracting cycle for open competitive tender, selective tender, and single sourcing tender to 180, 178, and 128 working days respectively compared with the current best effort performance of 327, 333, and 185 working days respectively.
Speaking at the MoU signing, the GCEO NNPC Ltd., Mr. Mele Kyari said signing the agreement heralds exciting times for the nation‚Äôs oil and gas industry and stands as a bold testimony that the Company is plunging into the future of hope, productivity and success. 
Kyari, who was represented at the occasion by NNPC Ltd‚Äôs Executive Vice President, Upstream, Mrs. Oritsemeyiwa Eyesan, added that with oil and gas as the bedrock of Nigeria‚Äôs economy, there is the need to get the contracting process in the Industry right so as to get the economy back on track.
In his remarks, the Executive Secretary, NCDMB, Engr. Simbi Wabote, described the MoU signing as a way forward and a critical step towards enhancing the nation‚Äôs crude oil production.
In their various remarks, the IOCs, represented by the MDs/Country Chairs of Shell, ExxonMobil, Chevron, TotalEnergies and ENI all pledged their commitment and support towards the implementation of the MoU for the benefit of all parties.
The framework is in line with the Nigerian Upstream Cost Optimization Program (NUCOP) and in consonance with Mr. President's directive for NNPC Ltd. and NCDMB to engage the industry with the objective of improving the performance of the petroleum industry. 
The development is also in line with the key mandates of NNPC Ltd under the PIA‚Äôs Article 53 (7) which empowers it to operate as a commercial entity in a profitable and efficient manner, as the National Energy Company.
The mandate for efficiency requires that NNPC Ltd. is committed to working with its partners in ensuring key processes, procedures, and timelines that drive major business activities such as contracting, are structured in a manner that engenders efficiency and drives profitability.
SIGNED:
Management
NNPC Ltd 
25th September, 2023.

As it winds down, I wanted to share some thoughts with regard to #GG18 and some of the controversies that came up in this round, specifically the Shell funding.
First I think division in the Gitcoin community is not good. We need to stay united to achieve the scale of impact we strive for. Despite differences in opinion, the community needs to stay cohesive and avoid splintering.
Second, I believe that those corporations that have caused the climate crisis by prioritizing the maximization of wealth at the expense of the climate, should not be allowed to greenwash. We need to continue holding them to account and demanding they stop destroying the climate. We should not celebrate them even if they donate to good causes.
That being said, we also need to be alive to the fact that there just isn't enough funding in the climate space to sustain the various regenerative projects happening around the world. Many projects are operating with less than optimal funding, and this holds back a lot of progress. In fact, we need many more new projects to be launched if we are to scale impact in time to avert disaster.
We need to find new sources of funding if the impact being targeted is to be at a scale that can turn the tide against climate change. Climate action needs to be scaled up by factors from where it currently is. None of this can happen without new funds flowing into the ecosystem.
Unfortunately, we do not have the luxury of time to figure out perfect solutions. At the rate we are going 2 degrees rise in global temperatures is probably already locked in at this point. If we don't take radical action immediately then we will be talking about avoiding a rise of 4 degrees. And by then, with warming feedback loops already activated, it'll be too late.
We need to drastically scale up climate action now. Not in a few years time. And the only way to do that is to find more resources to put into projects. Public goods funding is one great way to raise part of what's required. 
Getting corporates like Shell to contribute to the climate round is another. These corporations make money every time we drive, fly, or even order groceries. Part of those funds should flow back to supporting climate action. 
Oil companies continue to make profits because the world continues to use fossil fuels to drive the economy. Until the day that stops, it's only fair that these companies release some of the profits they make to projects working to fix the mess created by their businesses.
We shouldn't be asking companies like Shell to donate to Gitcoin whatever they wish. We should be demanding that all such companies and their associates dedicate a certain percentage of their profits to funding climate projects. It's the least they can do to stem the damage caused by their actions.
I can understand the point of view of those who reject the funds as being dirty money. I respect the decision of those who have decided to opt out of receiving these funds. I also equally respect the decision of those projects that have opted in. I don't think either one is necessarily wrong, I believe it all comes down to personal opinion.
From where I stand, it feels like we are giving these companies a free pass if we don't demand that they pay for the mess they made to be fixed. If we don't take that money, we are allowing them to go scot-free and pass the cleanup bill to someone else.
If big oil companies like Chevron, ExxonMobil, Shell, Total, and others were pressured by their consumers to pay for the cleanup of the climate; this would translate to a flurry of projects on the ground as new resources are unlocked. This is particularly the case for the Global South where climate financing is woefully lagging.
Requiring oil companies to pay their part is not synonymous with greenwashing. Nobody is going to be congratulating them for doing what they should have been doing since long ago. Calls for the phasing out of fossil fuels should grow stronger and such companies put under pressure till it happens. We aren't giving them a break and we certainly aren't celebrating them.
What we are saying is that until the day comes when these companies close shop, they should pay up. It's their fault things are where they are ecologically, and thus their responsibility to pay for it to be fixed. If they have grown aware of this and begun taking action through donating to #Gitcoin, I think this is something to be encouraged not the reverse.
With reference to the meme I posted above, I once again want to urge community cohesion. Let's not have a situation where projects that accept Shell funding get castigated or otherwise. The climate space needs tolerance for a wide array of opinions. Nobody has all the answers. And some solutions to current challenges (e.g. the funding gap) may not always be perfect. 
In future climate rounds, I would like to see even more corporations donate as a way of paying climate reparations. These new resources will fund a wave of innovation and regeneration across the globe, allowing timely interventions to a fast-deteriorating situation.
In conclusion, I want to pass a round of thanks to the entire @gitcoin team for another successful round. I also wish to thank the Gitcoin community including both the grantees and donors for coming together to build and fund what matters. Ya'll are awesome!
